docs.title: Computational Methods of Applied Physics (Spring 2026)
docs.text:
Meeting: Tue/Thu 3:05–4:20 Instructor: Your Name Office hours: TBD Email: you@school.edu

Course format

Tuesdays are concept + skill-building days (live coding “Simon Says” style). Thursdays are paired-programming labs. Whatever you don’t finish in lab becomes the homework.

docs.title: Quick links
docs.text:
• Syllabus
  • Calendar
  • Lessons (Tue)
  • Labs (Thu)
  • Assignments
  • Projects
  • Resources
  • Rendered Notes

docs.title: Calendar (Weeks 1–10)
docs.text:
This is the pre-project plan. Project weeks begin in Week 11.

Week Tuesday (Concept & Skill Building) Thursday (Paired Programming Lab → HW) 1 Intro to computational physics; environment; syntax; variables; simple I/O Lab 1: First steps; basic calculations; translate formulas into code 2 Data structures; plotting; example: constant-acceleration plots Lab 2: 1D kinematics; read data; compute v, a; plot with units 3 Control flow: conditionals + loops; example: projectile max height Lab 3: Projectile motion; with/without drag; integrate Newton’s 2nd law 4 Functions; modular code; documentation Lab 4: E&M superposition; point charges; vector field plots 5 Linear algebra: Ax=b; solving with libraries Lab 5: Circuit analysis with Kirchhoff + linalg.solve; testing/validation 6 ODE integration: Euler, Euler–Cromer; stability/error Lab 6: SHO; compare methods; energy conservation 7 Runge–Kutta + library solvers; solve_ivp Lab 7: Damped/driven oscillator; phase space; resonance/chaos 8 Coupled ODE systems; normal modes; eigenproblems Lab 8: Coupled oscillators; eigensystem; mode shapes 9 Model fitting + optimization; least squares; uncertainty Lab 9: Fit falling-object data; linear vs quadratic drag 10 Randomness + Monte Carlo ideas Lab 10: Radioactive decay sim; histogram + exponential fit

docs.title: Course info
docs.text:
• Course: PHYS 298 — Special Topics — Computational Methods of Applied Physics
  • Term: Spring 2026
  • Meeting: Tue/Thu 3:05–4:20

docs.title: Learning goals
docs.text: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. Translate a physics model into working code. 2. Visualize and interpret computational results. 3. Use numerical methods (linear algebra, ODE solvers, fitting, Monte Carlo). 4. Communicate results with clear plots, explanations, and reproducible scripts.

docs.title: Assignments
docs.text:
Homework is usually: finish the Thursday lab + a few extension questions.

Each HW page spells out what to submit (typically a .py file and 1–2 plots).

docs.title: Core task
docs.text: Finish Week 01 Thursday lab and submit: - your completed script (.py) - required plots (.png) or a short write-up (.pdf) as instructed

docs.title: Where to start
docs.text:
• Lab page: Week 01 Lab
  • Tutorial notes: Week 01 Thu notes

docs.title: Submission checklist
docs.text:
• Code runs top-to-bottom with no errors
  • Plots have labels + units
  • Short comments explain choices

docs.title: Labs (Thursdays)
docs.text:
Thursdays are paired-programming labs: - You get a drafted tutorial script with cells. - You fill in blanks / run experiments / extend the model. - Anything unfinished becomes the homework set for the week.

Each lab page links to the corresponding rendered Notes (Thu).

docs.title: Week 1 (Thu) — Lab 1: First steps; translate formulas into code
In-class plan
docs.text:
• Work through the tutorial script cell-by-cell.
  • Fill in TODO sections.
  • Produce the required plots.

docs.title: Notes (rendered tutorial)
docs.text: • Week 01 Thu lab notes

docs.title: What to submit (becomes HW)
docs.text:
• A completed .py file (your solution)
  • Plots saved to png (or embedded in a short PDF)

docs.title: Extension questions (optional / challenge)
docs.text:
• Add one more feature or parameter sweep.
  • Compare against an analytic limit if available.

docs.title: Lessons (Tuesdays)
docs.text:
Tuesdays are “talk + build” days: - We introduce the physics idea + computational skill. - We live-code a short script (Spyder cells). - The script is posted under Notes (rendered) as a browsable page.

  • Week 1 - Intro
  • Week 2 - Intro
  • Week 3 - Intro
  • Week 4 - Intro
  • Week 5 - Intro
  • Week 6 - Intro
  • Week 7 - Intro
  • Week 8 - Intro
  • Week 9 - Intro
  • Week 10 - Intro

docs.title: Notes (rendered from class scripts)
docs.text: These pages are generated from docs/notes/*.py files using Jupytext → .ipynb, then rendered by mkdocs-jupyter.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
1. Edit the .py in Spyder (cells with # %% and # %% [markdown])
  2. Run python tools/sync_notes.py to update .ipynb
  3. Commit + push

docs.title: Week 01 thu
docs.text:
In [ ]: Copied! 
g = 9.81  # m/s^2

m = 0.150   # kg
v = 8.0     # m/s
dy = 1.2    # m

# TODO: compute K and dU
K = 0.5 * m * v**2
dU = m * g * dy

print("K =", K, "J")
print("ΔU =", dU, "J")
g = 9.81 # m/s^2 m = 0.150 # kg v = 8.0 # m/s dy = 1.2 # m # TODO: compute K and dU K = 0.5 * m * v**2 dU = m * g * dy print("K =", K, "J") print("ΔU =", dU, "J") In [ ]: Copied! 
def kinetic_energy(m, v):
    """Return kinetic energy (J) for mass m (kg) and speed v (m/s)."""
    return 0.5 * m * v**2

print(kinetic_energy(0.150, 8.0))
def kinetic_energy(m, v): """Return kinetic energy (J) for mass m (kg) and speed v (m/s).""" return 0.5 * m * v**2 print(kinetic_energy(0.150, 8.0))

docs.title: Week 01 (Thu Lab) — First steps + translating formulas into code¶
docs.text:
Goal: Write a script that computes and prints a few physics quantities with units.

Work in pairs. One person “drives”, the other “navigates”.

docs.title: Task A — Basic calculations¶
docs.text:
Compute:

  • kinetic energy: (K = \tfrac12 m v^2)
  • gravitational potential change: (\Delta U = m g \Delta y)

docs.title: Task B — Make it reusable with a function¶
docs.text: Write a function kinetic_energy(m, v) that returns (\tfrac12 m v^2).

docs.title: Task C — Challenge¶
docs.text: Ask the user for m and v (input), compute K, and print a friendly sentence. (Remember: input() returns a string; convert to float.)

docs.text:

print("K =", K, "J")
print("ΔU =", dU, "J")
g = 9.81 # m/s^2 m = 0.150 # kg v = 8.0 # m/s dy = 1.2 # m # TODO: compute K and dU K = 0.5 * m * v**2 dU = m * g * dy print("K =", K, "J") print("ΔU =", dU, "J") In [ ]: Copied! 
def kinetic_energy(m, v):
    """Return kinetic energy (J) for mass m (kg) and speed v (m/s)."""
    return 0.5 * m * v**2

print(kinetic_energy(0.150, 8.0))
def kinetic_energy(m, v): """Return kinetic energy (J) for mass m (kg) and speed v (m/s).""" return 0.5 * m * v**2 print(kinetic_energy(0.150, 8.0))

docs.title: Week 01 (Thu Lab) — First steps + translating formulas into code¶
docs.text:
Goal: Write a script that computes and prints a few physics quantities with units.

Work in pairs. One person “drives”, the other “navigates”.

docs.title: Task A — Basic calculations¶
docs.text:
Compute:

  • kinetic energy: (K = \tfrac12 m v^2)
  • gravitational potential change: (\Delta U = m g \Delta y)

docs.title: Task B — Make it reusable with a function¶
docs.text: Write a function kinetic_energy(m, v) that returns (\tfrac12 m v^2).

docs.title: Task C — Challenge¶
docs.text: Ask the user for m and v (input), compute K, and print a friendly sentence. (Remember: input() returns a string; convert to float.)

docs.title: Week 01 tue
docs.text:
In [ ]: Copied! 
import numpy as np

g = 9.81  # m/s^2
v0 = 12.0 # m/s
theta_deg = 35.0

theta = np.deg2rad(theta_deg)
R = (v0**2 * np.sin(2*theta)) / g
R
import numpy as np g = 9.81 # m/s^2 v0 = 12.0 # m/s theta_deg = 35.0 theta = np.deg2rad(theta_deg) R = (v0**2 * np.sin(2*theta)) / g R In [ ]: Copied! 
theta_deg = 45.0
theta = np.deg2rad(theta_deg)
R = (v0**2 * np.sin(2*theta)) / g
R
theta_deg = 45.0 theta = np.deg2rad(theta_deg) R = (v0**2 * np.sin(2*theta)) / g R

docs.title: Week 01 (Tue) — Intro + your first physics script¶
docs.text:
Today we’ll:

  • get comfortable running a script
  • use variables + units
  • compute something familiar (constant acceleration)

docs.title: A tiny “physics calculator”¶
docs.text:
We’ll compute the range for a projectile launched from level ground (no drag):

[ R = \frac{v_0^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g} ]

Later we’ll replace this with a numerical simulation.

docs.title: Quick check¶
docs.text: Change theta_deg to 45° and confirm you get the maximum range.

docs.title: Week 10 (Tue) — Random processes; Monte Carlo ideas¶
Final Project (Weeks 11–14)
docs.text: In the final third of the course, you’ll choose a physics system and build a computational investigation: - proposal - reproducible code + plots - short written report - final presentation

docs.title: Project Check-ins
docs.text: Week 12: short status updates + peer feedback Week 13: rehearsal + polishing figures/slides

docs.title: Final Deliverables
docs.text:
• Code repo (clean, runnable)
  • Final report (PDF)
  • Slides (PDF)
  • 8–10 minute presentation

docs.title: Project Proposal
docs.text:
Due: Week 11 (date TBD)

Include: - system/question - model equations - parameters + data sources (if any) - planned simulations/figures - division of labor
